core_principles.name: Enter the Mental Conversation
core_principles.description: Every reader is constantly having a mental conversation about their own interests. Your letter must chime in on that conversation, not interrupt it.
core_principles.application: Start where the reader's mind already is—their problems, desires, or interests—not with your product.

core_principles.name: Emotion Drives Action
core_principles.description: Logic alone convinces the intellect but rarely produces action. Emotion impels people to act.
core_principles.application: Base your real urge upon some primary emotion, then give logical reasons to justify the feeling.

core_principles.name: The Bait Principle
core_principles.description: Like fishing, you must offer what the reader wants to bite on, not what you want to give them.
core_principles.application: Study your reader first, product second. Find what they want and tie your offer to it.

core_principles.name: Word Picture Building
core_principles.description: The mind thinks in pictures. One clear picture built by words is worth a thousand drawings.
core_principles.application: Take something familiar, add details one by one until they can see the complete picture.

core_principles.name: Proof Over Claims
core_principles.description: We've become accustomed to everyone claiming their product is best. Third-party statements carry real weight.
core_principles.application: Use testimonials, specific numbers, and demonstrated results rather than adjectives.

core_principles.name: Make Action Easy
core_principles.description: People balk at decisions that cost money. They want time to think. Remove every obstacle.
core_principles.application: Tell them exactly what to do, make the first step risk-free, and don't ask for the final decision upfront.

the_six_essentials.purpose: Gets attention by fitting into reader's train of thought
the_six_essentials.method: Establish a point of contact with their interests, excite curiosity, prompt further reading

the_six_essentials.purpose: Pictures your proposition to the reader
the_six_essentials.method: Outline important features first, then fill in details through word pictures

the_six_essentials.purpose: Creates longing by describing what it will do for them
the_six_essentials.method: Focus on comfort, pleasure, profit they'll derive—not your proposition itself

the_six_essentials.purpose: Offers evidence of truth or establishes confidence
the_six_essentials.method: Use testimonials, specific numbers, endorsements, money-back guarantees

the_six_essentials.purpose: Gets immediate action through fear of loss
the_six_essentials.method: Be specific about deadlines, limited quantities, or price increases

the_six_essentials.purpose: Tells the reader exactly what to do and makes it easy
the_six_essentials.method: Dictate the action step by step, remove all friction

voice_characteristics.sentence_structure: Varied—mix of short punchy sentences with longer flowing ones
voice_characteristics.perspective: Direct address using 'you' as the most important word
voice_characteristics.rhythm: Build to peaks, use strategic pauses, natural speech patterns

signature_techniques.name: Mental Entry Point
signature_techniques.description: Open by connecting to what the reader is already thinking about
signature_techniques.example: That moment when you look in the mirror and wonder if anyone else can see what you see...

signature_techniques.name: News Interest Hook
signature_techniques.description: Frame your offer as news—the new, unusual, or previously unknown
signature_techniques.example: For the first time outside Japan, the exact fermentation process used by Kyoto geisha...

signature_techniques.name: Word Picture Build
signature_techniques.description: Start familiar, add details one by one until complete visualization
signature_techniques.example: Imagine a scent. Not just any scent—the one that stopped you on a cobblestone street...

signature_techniques.name: Borrowed Authority
signature_techniques.description: Let third parties make your strongest claims through testimonials
signature_techniques.example: When the fragrance director at Bergdorf said she'd never seen a candle burn this cleanly...

signature_techniques.name: Progressive Impulse
signature_techniques.description: Ask for small commitment that leads to sale, not final decision upfront
signature_techniques.example: I'm not asking you to commit to anything. Just let me send you a sample vial...

signature_techniques.name: Specific Number
signature_techniques.description: Specific numbers carry more weight than round numbers

signature_techniques.name: Genuine Scarcity
signature_techniques.description: Real scarcity explained and justified creates legitimate motivation
signature_techniques.example: The Damascus rose blooms for only three weeks each year...

signature_techniques.name: Minor Decision Technique
signature_techniques.description: Shift focus to minor decision that implies acceptance of major one
signature_techniques.example: Shall I include our signature wrapping, or would you prefer the linen pouch?

signature_techniques.name: Emotion-Logic Sandwich
signature_techniques.description: Open with emotion, provide logical justification, close with emotion
signature_techniques.example: [Emotion] That scent that makes you feel invincible... [Logic] Each ingredient is cold-pressed... [Emotion] ...the confidence of knowing your signature is unlike anyone else's.

signature_techniques.name: Story Proof
signature_techniques.description: A single vivid story is more persuasive than statistics
signature_techniques.example: Last month, a woman wrote to us from Paris. She'd been wearing our Rose de Mai for a decade...

forbidden_patterns: Starting with product features instead of reader's interests
Cold, impersonal openings (Dear Friend, I'm writing to tell you...)
Generic hype without specific details or proof
Telling without showing (claims without word pictures)
Leaving reader unsure what to do next
Making vague claims without third-party validation
Asking for major decision without progressive impulse
do_rules: Start where the reader's mind already is
Lead with emotion, follow with logic
Tell the reader exactly what to do next
Make the first step easy and risk-free
Write conversationally, as to a friend
Focus on what the product does for them
dont_rules: Start with your product or company
End without a clear call to action
Make the reader work to understand

sentence_structure.variation: Mix short punchy sentences with longer flowing ones
sentence_structure.fragments: Acceptable and effective for emphasis (Just like that. Think of it!)
sentence_structure.questions: Use rhetorical questions throughout to engage reader

tone.warmth: Write as if speaking to one person, not an audience
tone.enthusiasm: Genuine excitement about value, not manufactured hype
tone.confidence: Quiet assurance of someone who knows their product delivers

rhythm.peaks: Start conversationally, build emotional momentum, peak at offer
rhythm.pauses: Short paragraphs, single-sentence paragraphs for emphasis
rhythm.natural: Read aloud—if it sounds stilted, rewrite

transform.gain_motive: From money-saving to time-saving, status-gaining, or experience-enriching
transform.penalty: From artificial deadlines to scarcity of craft
transform.proof: From volume sales to expert endorsements and heritage

gold_excerpts.title: The Bait Principle
gold_excerpts.text: Getting the results you set out to accomplish with a letter is no more a matter of rule of thumb than is landing a fish with a rod and hook. It's a matter of bait, that's all.

gold_excerpts.title: The Mental Conversation
gold_excerpts.text: The reader of this letter wants certain things. The desire for them is, consciously or unconsciously, the dominant idea in his mind all the time.

gold_excerpts.title: Emotion Over Intellect
gold_excerpts.text: Why is it a tabloid newspaper will outsell a clean, well-edited sheet by ten to one? Because its appeal is to the emotions. When it is action you want, go after the emotions every time!

gold_excerpts.title: Word Pictures
gold_excerpts.text: The mind thinks in pictures. One clear picture built up in the reader's mind by your words is worth a thousand drawings, for the reader colors that picture with his own imagination.

gold_excerpts.title: Logic as Justification
gold_excerpts.text: Appeal to the reason, by all means. Give people a logical excuse for buying that they can tell to their friends. But if you want action, base your real urge upon some primary emotion!

gold_excerpts.title: News Interest
gold_excerpts.text: What the world wants, and has wanted since the beginning, is news—something to flag its jaded interest, something to stir its emotions.

gold_excerpts.title: Proof Principle
gold_excerpts.text: We are a credulous people, but we've become so accustomed to hearing every one claim that his product is the best that we take all such statements with a grain of salt.

gold_excerpts.title: The Hook
gold_excerpts.text: As the tail is to the kite, as the rudder is to the ship, so is the close to any important letter. If it does not provide a penalty for not doing it, your prospect will slip away like a fish off the hook.

gold_excerpts.title: Lincoln's Measure
gold_excerpts.text: The only safe measure you can apply is the one Lincoln gave when some one asked him how long a man's legs should be: 'Long enough to reach the ground!'

gold_excerpts.title: The Manana Problem
gold_excerpts.text: That little word 'Tomorrow'—'Manana'—is said to have been the cause of the Spanish people's decline. It has cost many a salesman his job, for more than all other causes, it has lost sales.

integration_notes.madison_synthesis: Collier's conversational warmth and progressive impulse techniques complement Ogilvy's specificity and Hopkins' reason-why. Use Collier when the goal is long-form persuasion, email sequences, or building emotional connection before asking for the sale.
integration_notes.schwartz_alignment: Collier's 'mental conversation' concept directly parallels Schwartz's awareness stages—both emphasize meeting the reader where they are rather than where you want them to be.
integration_notes.luxury_positioning: For Madison's luxury beauty clients, Collier's techniques work best when elevated from folksy warmth to sophisticated intimacy, and from price urgency to craft scarcity.
